ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: Wonderful professor. He kept me very engaged, and was ALWAYS accessible to help with questions/concerns.
N/A
If I were to do it again I would take the flipped class to get more practice using the methods by working through more examples.
Q10. Professor Reuning-Scherer is an incredible educator. He is patient, creative, clear, and dedicated to his students. It was always a pleasure to attend his class.
To answer #1, the comic book Jonathan suggested was really helpful!
This is as good as it gets in a basic statistics course
The T.A., Madeline Rubenstein, was excellent and extremely helpful!
#8, 10 Really enthusiastic lectures, but sometimes it was too much. Especially when it's all going over my head.
Professor Reuning-Scherer is great, he makes himself available very often and is extremely helpful. His energy and sense of humor made the class very enjoyable!

Q8: I thought the professor was very engaging and obviously loves teaching, which is great. The lectures were very fast however, and sometimes it was hard for me to relate what we were learning to what we had learned. It seemed like the not-so-important stuff was given equal time as the need-to-know stuff, and it was hard to separate the two and understand how the material we were learning related to past material.
Good class! Definitely worth taking.
Question 12 The course was really useful and the professor was always available to answer questions from students.

Your class, as it stands now, is an undergraduate course being taught to (mostly)graduate students. Redo your lectures, incorporating(FES students') research that applies each of the Stats models you want to teach. Have a new academic paper for us to read (each week?), then in class go over the model&data of the paper. This would be a more applied approach, causing us to look at Stats within other publications with a critical eye. This would teach us stats concepts; we are not statisticians. Also, at least 1/3class days should be spent in the computer lab. You treat Minitab like a footnote of the class. Minitab is actually wildly important for the homework and so much time is wasted by your 100+ students trying to click through Minitab. Note: Other readings to consider for the class -"Naked Statistics." I would suggest this be reading during summer before coming to class or during 1st month of class. Footnote: Thank you for your energy in class. Your effort is noted and appreciated.

I felt that the classes were a little too fast and I did not manage to catch everything in class. However, the assignments helped to reinforce the concepts taught in class. I find the class really helpful as it allowed me to better understand scientific papers and I could put to use some of the statistic analysis in my projects immediately.

I had never taken statistics before this course, but had a good math background. I feel like completing the assignments really brought the lessons home for me. However, I would soon forget the concepts and have to go back and relearn them multiple times in the semester. Now, at the end of the semester, despite the fact that I got a decent grade, I feel like I've forgotten most of what I learned and should probably take an introductory course again. It's hard for me to tell if this is due to my learning style, the professor's teaching style, the fact that I hadn't done math in a while, or something else.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The professor.
Statistics was made accessible. The instructor explains concepts very clearly.
The contents of this course themselves are very useful, and the instructor explains them in a very easy-to-understand way!
Honestly Jonathan makes this class worth it. He has a great ability to present boring material in an exciting and fun way, which is important for a stats class.

The availability of Jonathan. I don't have any other classes where I feel that the professor is always available for questions and additional help. I really appreciated the time he takes in helping students understand the material well.
Professor is a great guy (and I do like his jokes); learned a lot of important statistical analyses and how/when to use them
The topic is interesting and relevant to life in general

The professor teaches in an engaging and fun way. I laughed more in Stats class than any other class, which is extremely useful, as I have a tendency to disengage with math. The case studies were helpful, as were the step-by-step notes. Rather than getting stressed by math, I actually enjoyed coming to class. I will remember enough of the subject matter to be able to analyze reports in scientific studies with a more careful eye. The final project can be as easy or as difficult as you like, and the professor is very available to help.
Jonathan's light-hearted and effective way of delivering the lesson and concepts.
Teacher, final project

- Access to his excellent lecture notes and slides ahead of time. - Prolific use of examples to illustrate concepts. - Revisiting past concepts often in relation to new content. - Inclusion of software-specific instructions for each statistical concept. Professor Reuning-Scherer's energy and enthusiasm!

The best aspects of this course was how clearly Jonathan was able to convey some really complicated concepts. I also really appreciate his organized class notes that we can keep with us and continue to refer back to throughout our studies. Those notes will continue to be very useful.
Fun to go to class, intense learning, clearly taught

JDRS was probably the best part. He was energetic and funny and really committed to students learning the material. He made something which could have been very dry actually interesting and enjoyable.
Extremely clear explanations in a non-jargon fashion by the instructor.
Being able to reference the lecture slides during homework problems and take-home midterms was very useful.
I got the most from the clicker questions and game show style review lectures.
The professor was very thorough when presenting the material and his presentations we excellent and very useful when working on the weekly assignments
I really enjoyed the willingness to explain and the sense of humor the professor has. Makes easier learning statistics.
Homework assignments were very relevant and helped me to learn the material. JDRS's jokes.

The professor was extremely accessible during and outside of regular class hours. I really appreciated this and feel like this was where much of my learning took place. Also, the TAs were phenomenal, especially Madeline and Kevin whom I interacted with the most.
The best part was the final project as it brought everything in the course full circle.
Real world examples in class!
Workload not overwhelming, but I still felt like I learned a lot.
This course was fast paced but very helpful for my understanding of statistics. I liked the hands-on assignments to better grasp the concepts.
The class lectures
The good attitude of the professor and he was very helpful.
-We covered basic statistics. -The professor brought a positive attitude. -TAs were regularly available.
The lecturer really made the class more interesting and engaging then what a typical stats class would be. The tools that we can get out of it!
The enthusiasm of the professor and the support of both professor and TAs.
Very entertaining lectures and assignments that made me get the concepts.
Having the recorded lectures and the notes online to consult whenever possible.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: An earlier start on the final project would be helpful.
Maybe some of the homework assignments could be shortened
Jonathan moves very quickly, understandably since there is so much to cover, but I sometimes would feel confused in lectures until I went home later and re-looked at the material or spoke to a TA.

My biggest crit, besides that the material is unfortunately inherently kinda boring, is that whenever I went to get help from the professor or TA in an unstructured time period (i.e. sometimes the professor lets us sign up for 15 min time slots for help, but in this case I am talking about otherwise when he just has Office Hours), I always had to wait at least half an hour for them to get to me since there were so many other students, even when I got there 10 minutes after office hours started. I also felt bad about asking too many questions or asking the TA to further clarify since there were so many students waiting behind me. So I felt I wasn't able to use the TA or professor for help as well as I would've liked to.
It should be more engaging of the class. Jonathan is great and always upbeat but the course itself is dealing with a topic that needs to hvae more active student participation.

I liked the time in class towards the end when we worked in small groups to decide which statistical model was most applicable to the studies presented. A few more moments of group work in class would be nice. Otherwise, excellent.
More homework (for practice)!
The lectures go perhaps a little bit too fast
It goes very fast. It's sort of inevitable because of everything we have to cover, but one or two things could probably be cut out just so everything goes a little slower

The course moves very quickly. Class is dismissed early on most days, which I gather is by design since it's hard to hold students' attention for longer when discussing stats. However, I think on days when a particularly tricky topic is being covered, it would be beneficial to slow down the pace, use more examples and use the full class time.

Not very interactive, beside answering "ZERO" every once in a while. More problems and lectures with examples from environmental studies or research would help me key in a little more. It would be more obvious of when to use different tests.
I think it's a lot of material to cover in one semester so it might be useful to assign or strongly recommend one specific book for the whole semester
Making videos available to be able to consult them after class to help resolve doubts.
More information on what the final project is supposed to be - the examples were very different form what JDRS seemed to actually want. Sometimes, I wanted JDRS to slow down. JDRS's jokes.

I would have appreciated more screen shots for the MINITAB work - the prof. went through examples really quickly in class and it was hard to replicate what he had done in class later on the homework since the slides with MINITAB instructions were sometimes incomplete.
n/a
The assignments and midterms are more than enough to test and engage the students. I think the final project is unecessary and adds a heavy load at the end of the semester.
Minitab for Mac - I feel it hindered my ability to learn by not having it on my own computer and ability to use it at anytime.
No need for improvement--this course is great.
Sometimes some classes were too fast, but the problem sets were useful to review the concepts that were taught in class.
See note above^
I wish that it was a little slower so that we can have the time to absorb and understand before moving on. A few more examples would be helpful.

Especially for internationals it could be hard to keep up with the pace of the professor's explanations, which made it more difficult to understand. Questions on take home exams could be confusing. There was no book but books were suggested - that might be considered to do differently, but maybe not necessary. Slides were already very helpful.

-The course was based on Minitab, which doesn't work on Macs unless you partition your drive, which Yale can not currently do for students. It would be good to either use a different program or find a way to use it on Macs. -The TA's were great, however, most of the times I went, they were too busy because of the volume of students. It would be good to have two TA's on duty especially closer to when assignments are due.
Minitab is a great program, but I have a hard time working in public spaces on statistics without getting distracted-- because I have a Macintosh I could not work on my homework often while at home.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: No lab

Both lectures and labs were very helpful to understand theoretical and real-world application of statistics. I do wish there was more reference for real-world applications although topics might be out of the syllabus.
It was effective.
The office hours with the TA's were very useful as well as those with the professor. There could be more variety of hours with the TA's.
TA really know the material and make sure you understand anything that you ask. Having that many office hours was great and really helpful. Helped my learning process.
Effective.
This course helped me relate data analysis concepts to other my other classes.
My TA (Kevin) was great! Very helpful.
The course lectures were very helpful with the out-of-class assignments and the notes were very useful.
Maybe work on particular problems in lecture more.
The discussion sections were very useful.
See note above^
Yes, it helped to clarify concepts in class.

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: As a science major (undergrad) I needed an introduction to basic statistics. I appreciated the environmental science focus.
This course is essential to my studies.
For my scientific research in atmospheric science, it's useful to know the statistical analysis to analysis the relationships, uncertainties and other mechanisms.
Stats are important for my masters work, and this class was exactly what I needed in order to learn the basics.

This course has really helped me understand when and why statistical analyses are used. I am already seeing improvement in my reading and critique of scientific papers (my eyes used to glaze when reading statistical methods). I may even suggest finding excerpts of scientific article methods and asking the class why these scientists used these statistical methods (was it right, wrong, should they use another?). This could be helpful for us in critiquing scientific literature.

Stats is important to any major where you're doing some sort of quantitative analysis of some [large] group of data, beyond just mean/median/mode stuff. But honestly I don't foresee myself using stats in my particular discipline, since we're often doing different sorts of analyses (I think he mentioned spatial analyses?) besides correlation between variables.
It doesn't fit into my program per se, it just is relevant to life in general (reading academic articles, understanding sampling rates, etc.)

This class made me more capable of analyzing statistical models, like those seen in scientific studies. I work in the protected areas management realm, and I think future employers would approve of this course material.
It will help with my understanding and application for data analysis for my summer project.
Valuable for people in any field. For me it is particularly useful to scrutinize "every day statistics" and those related to my course of study.
Statistics is good to know for research.

Everyone vaguely interested in science should take statistics, particularly those interested in environmental science. It's not only interesting and relevant, it helps a lot with readings of other papers and helps one better analyze other people's work. Really everyone at FES should probably have to take some sort of statistics class.
Stats refresher was needed. This is the best stats course I've taken.
I'm not sure how exactly it will apply, but I feel a solid foundation of statistical knowledge is important.
Statistics is very useful when reading and understanding scientific papers, we do this a lot in other classes, so it was great knowing that I could understand the methodology for the studies.
Great! It is always important to have a basic understanding of statistics.
This course will greatly help me in understanding how to interpret scientific data and its use in communicating management of a resource.
I will need regression analysis for my thesis studies.

Since I plan to be involved in environmental policy, I believe that it is important to be able to read scientific papers and understand what is being argued/described. I want to be able to support my decisions with sound environmental science.
The material is very helpful for my overall program and it was very important for me to take this course because I will use statistics for some other projects.
Statistics is vitally important to my future research in the environmental field.

It was a good refresher and it thought me additional statistical tools which I did not have. It will definitely help me understand how numbers in reports are churned and help to question the basis of these numbers when necessary.

I used the skills learnt in this class already in other 1st semester courses and papers, so that was really great. Feel much more confident about stats now and feel that I will be able to apply it to other environment related research.
I will be conducting social science research, which will definitely require understanding statistics.

A basic understanding will be helpful, and give me a leg up in comprehension of ancillary professional materials, but I doubt I will ever use most of what I learned in this class. By and large the course served me best in stretching my mind and mode of understanding and thinking through problems.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: The material in this course is very valuable to my research.
I had previously taken a stats class, but that instructor at my undergrad university was terrible. Jonathan made the concepts more accessible to me.
Requirement; not good enough at math to take other stats courses, haha.
I had never taken stats before
Refresher, ability to discern good studies, more confidence diving into my own research, future employability.
I wanted a refresher for biostatistics that I took for undergrad, years ago :p
Wanted to continue to engage in statistics so that I have fighting chance of retaining the information for future use.
Analyze data from my summer research.
To help with my research.
How can you do environmental policy if you don't understand statistics?
For the reasons above. It's sort of crucial in environmental studies and I thought it would make me a better scientist.
Needed to refresh stats in preparation of research.
Mostly because it is highly recommended by the school for MEM students.
I think everyone, even people who only want to be managers or work in policy, need to understand stats and how to mathematically demonstrate experiments.
It can be very useful for doing research studies.
To have a beter understanding of statistical concepts.
I had taken stats many years ago. This was a great refresher and good to update my knowledge.
I took this course to be more comfortable with statistics
Math class of some sort was needed for my program.
I need to get my head around stats and the course helped a lot
Needed
Because I wanted to learn more about statistics and because it had been a long time since I took a course about it.
I wanted a refresher on stats and wanted to pick up some basis regression analysis techniques.
To gain better stats skills.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes.
yes.
Yes, I got exactly what I want to learn from this class!
Yes, this course met my expectations.
Yes.
Yes! I (re)learned a lot of stats stuff.
Yes
Yes, absolutely.
Would have liked more problems in the homework for extra practice. I learn by way of copious examples.
Absolutely. Extremely helpful.
Yes!
YES!!!

Absolutely. I learned so much and I can already see my analytical skills improving as I read papers for other classes. I wasn't expecting to actually enjoy the material (as in, I thought it would be useful but not interesting) but I was actually wrong. I enjoyed doing the work for this class and I thought it was all interesting.
Exceeded expectations
For the most part, yes. It's disappointing that Minitab is not really used in the professional world though.
Sure.
Yes!
Yes, exceed my expectations.
Yes
yes.
Yes the course met my expectations.
Yes.
Yes.
Yes, I now feel able to decipher statistics and understand how conclusions are drawn from data.
Yes and more. I will be taking a more comprehensive stats course next semester
Yes
Yes, the topics were interesting and very useful.
Yes.
Yes. Probably I even learnt more than I would have expected.
No. I got a 98 and a 90 on the mid terms, but somehow I feel like I understand/remember very little about statistics right now at the end of the semester.
Yes.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: Through group discussion for the final project, I got deeper understanding of the knowledge and methods that I learned from the class.

Advantages: working with people was the best way to learn from one another and solve difficult problems together. Disadvantages: when working with people on homework and group projects, it became much harder to do the midterms individually because you became reliant on the other people to some extent

It helps to do statistics with classmates on homework and projects. It helped me to talk through my thought process and discuss why to perform a test in a specific way...and to talk through the 'why does it look like this?! What happened?!'
Everything went smoothly for our final project. It was good to have other people to take on the work load as well as bounce ideas off of

Looking for a useful and meaningful data set was somewhat annoying. As this was real-world data I found myself having to consult with Jonathan alot more as things didn't fit nicely into a box, this was very helpful in giving my a realistic expectation of future statistical work.
I worked as a team on the final project - it makes it more fun, and it is much better to have another person to discuss the concepts and issues with

There was clearly a preference for group work based on the instructions for the final project. Variability in stats and writing ability made it tough for there to be equitable participation by group members, but maybe that's not necessarily a function of the group work design, but the profile of my particular group?
It was my favorite part of the course.
We only participated in a group work for the final project. It worked out very well as we had time to focus on one area of the project. A disadvantage is trying to work with different schedules.
I really enjoyed working in a group. Learned a lot from my teammates.
I appreciated being able to do the homework and the final project as a group. I think we helped each other a lot in our learning.
Its always great to know that there aren't any right answers in some stats problems. The groups helped in this regard.

The advantages were that we could collaborate together to use what we learned in class and join our knowledge. A disadvantage is that our schedules were different so we needed to organize the time to work together.
Group projects are the absolute worst. Always.
It is helpful to split the work up and to be able to talk to someone about issues that you have.
As always, when you work together you can learn from each other and have discussions about the material, which is a good (better) way of learning.

Much of the statistical inquiry and material importantly rely on good practices and there are rarely absolute solutions-- so working as a group for the final project was instructive in bouncing ideas off of one another and reflecting on individual thoughts, decisions, conclusions.

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Actually go to the lectures; they're helpful, and entertaining!
Remember to review what the professor teaches in class afterwards, or it's easy to forget the old knowledge as you learn new ones.
A textbook is not necessary, but it can be helpful.
As other students said before, stay on top of the material.

Starting the pset like the day or two after it's assigned, rather than the day or two before it's due, is always a good idea. Try to get lots of help from the TA or professor, even if it's a long wait to do so...
Stay up to date with the class work. Falling behind is a bad idea.
It's an excellent statistics course. Take it if that's what you're looking for.
The readings and weekly office hours helped alot if you are lost. Just go even if you don't have questions as other students might experience questions that you didn't know to ask.
Ask questions during class to ensure complete understanding
Take it!
Take it - you will not be sorry

Take advantage of JDRS- go to office hours, go to his open help sessions. They'll not only help you do better but also you'll get a better hold on the material. Also keep up. If you miss a class, be sure to watch it online and if you fall behind, be sure to ask for help. Besides the speed, this is actually a fun class that everyone should take
Do not bother buying a textbook unless you want to have one for reference - the lecture notes are all you need to succeed in this class.
Do the homework early and keep up on it. Don't try to take notes in class. The lecture happens way too fast for that to be an effective method.
Do not fall behind and work on all of the assignments.
Go to all the classes, take advantage of all the office hours and if you need to read a book to enhance your learning, the Cartoon guide is great.
Get help early and often!
Definitely take the class, it will go a long way in helping you understand data analysis.
If you need stats take it, but if you have time to take it over the summer before the program at your community college, that is better for your bottom line.
Worth taking. Good, comprehensive intro stats class. You learn a lot without much pressure.
Take the course if you want to have atleast some grounding in stats. What you learn may be the bare minimal that you will need in the field

Solve all the problem sets with time, because some might take more time than others and go to the discussion sections with the Teaching Assistants as well as with the professor. The professor was always available for the students to answer any doubts and he always showed a nice attitude to solve any question.

This is one of the best stats class I have ever been to. Stats is still stats but at least the lecturer tries to make it more interesting and manageable. Stats is important tool to have especially in scientific papers and also in policy making as alot of information come in through numbers and there is a need to understand how these numbers are generated to draw the right conclusions on them.
It can be rather time-consuming, but very valuable, especially when you don't have proper stats skills yet.
Print out the lecture notes and take notes on top of them. Get the cartoon guide to statistics and follow along in there. Go to the TA's sessions as much as you can.
Use the notes online and re-watch the recorded lectures on confusing material while browsing the notes.
